loans.name: Kashenshero United, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
Hard-working, 35-year-old Peace N. has a dependable sense of purpose as regards anything to do with her 8-year-old agro-produce business. She has worked tooth and nail to keep her business, which trades in bananas from the Kashenshero trading center. On the sunny side, her strong work ethic has gotten her far, as her business currently generates 300,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis.
 
With these modest earnings, she has been able to make the best of the bad bargains that have hit her business occasionally. She gleefully reveals how she is able to educate three out of her four children, who are undergoing different institutions of learning respectively with her small profits. 

With this loan, she envisions being financially empowered to buy more stock of bananas and further pay rent for the business shop as she looks at expansion into bigger markets and also to improve her household income from the sales of her business.

loans.use: Purchase more stock of bananas for resale

loans.name: Felicisima

texts.en: Felicisima F. is from the town of Banga. She is 59 years old. Felicisima is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Felicisima raises pigs for fattening and sale. Felicisima has been engaged in her business for over seven years. She was also able to put up a small sari-sari (variety) store that she hopes to grow as well. She sells various products that most of the people in her community buy from her. Felicisima joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felicisima is requesting a new loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. She also plans to add inventory to her store. This will be the first loan taken out by Felicisima from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc., (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but sldo offers savings, insurance and training programs through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. She also plans to add inventory to her store.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
This is Jocelyn A., 50, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Rosendo A., a tricycle (a motorcycle with sidecar) operator and driver. She is the mother of two children, one of whom is already working while the other is still in school. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her remaining child all the way through college. It's a dream for most Filipino parents like Jocelyn as she herself has been an elementary graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Jocelyn operates a tailoring business. She mainly offers curtains, bed sheets, blankets and other home trappings. Seasonal demands for different clothing like uniforms and such are available all year round. She also does repairs and alterations. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 200 Philippine pesos (php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php11,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. She has been a member of Center for Community Transformation for two years now and regularly attends fellowship meetings.   

Jocelyn dreams to be able to give all her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work with her business. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns

loans.name: Tuya

texts.en:
Mrs. Tuya is 32 years old. She lives with her husband and son Amgaabazar, 8, in an apartment they bought last year with a mortgage. Her husband works in a lemonade factory as a sales representative. 

Tuya used to work in a supermarket as a salesperson. In 2008, she decided to rent a place and open a small grocery shop.  Since then, she has been running her business quite successfully. But most of her profits of around 2,000,000 Mongolian Tugriks go to cover the rent at the moment. So she decided to build her own small shop and also, at the same time, increase her working capital and profit. Building work is 75% complete. The reason she is asking for the loan is to complete the building project before the wintertime and to move the business in.

loans.use: To complete the building project before the wintertime

loans.name: Esther Naisianoi

texts.en:
Esther Naisianoi K. is 29 years old and her spouse is Ezekiel. She supports three members of her family. Her spouse is also a farmer and they have been doing the farming together on their own piece of land for the last seven years.

This will be her second loan. She is planning to spend 20,000 Kenyan shillings to prepare the land for planting potatoes. With the anticipated profits from the expanded business, she is planning to increase her farm produce by plowing more acres and also to educate her children.

She has been paying back her loan successfully without default. Her hopes and dreams are to expand her farming activity from small-scale to large-scale and also to see her children get to a better school with good learning facilities.

She is hardworking and very determined in all her undertakings.

loans.use: She is planning to prepare the land for planting potatoes

loans.name: Rashad

texts.ru:
Rashid H. 31 let. On jenat i imeyet 2 detey , doch 10 let kotoraya uchitsya v shkole i zanimayetsya risovaniyem i sin 5 let. Rashid i eqo semya yavlyayutsya   oni pereselenci iz Fuzuli, seychas oni projivayut v Fuzuli regione, .

Rashid uje 5 let zanimayetsya skotovodstvom . Etomu biznesu on nauchilsya u svoeqo otca. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit  dlya razvitiya biznesa. Rashid prodayet na rinki molko i sir.
texts.en:
Rashid H. is thirty-one years old and has two children. His daughter is ten, goes to school and likes to draw, and his son is five. Rashid and his family live in the Fuzuli region. For five years Rashid has bred cattle, a trade he learned from his father. Rashid sells milk and cheese on the local market. Now he's asking for a loan of 2000 AZN to expand his business.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy calves

loans.name: Hovdohan

texts.en:
Hovdohan H. is 45 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Bayan-Ulgiy province, western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Two of his elder children, ages 16 and 13, attend a local secondary school. The youngest daughter goes to a local kindergarten while his wife manages a clothing retailing business in their town. 

Hovdohan has been operating a wooden products business since 1999, specializing in making dombor, a traditional Khazah musical instrument, in a small wood shop. He designs and produces the styles and sizes of the musical instrument that he sells throughout his community and has found success in his trade. 

His wife is in charge of the clothing business, which has working capital of 3,500,000 Mongolian Tugriks and makes supplement and inventory once a month. With the business profit, the family purchased a small car. 

For the future, Hovdohan says, "My main business goal is to continue to produce quality products and enlarge it by completing a newly built workplace for my customers." He is a very hardworking and modest person and is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more supplements in Urumchi, a border city of China.

loans.use: To purchase more supplements

loans.name: Gertrudes

texts.en:
This is Gertrudes T., 60, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Albino T., a carpenter, and is the mother of a young, well-rounded adult.

Gertrudes operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5-pesos-worth of cooking oil, or an egg.

Gertrudes earns by buying supplies at the wholesale price and selling them retail. Her store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns Php 200 in sales every day.

To help Gertrudes continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php 8,000 loan. She will use to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.

Gertrudes has been a member of Center for Community Transformation for almost five years now and regularly attends fellowship meetings*. 
 
Gertrudes dreams of living a comfortable and well-off life.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
This is Jennifer S., 32, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Lino S., a security guard. They are blessed in their marriage with good health and strong physiques that enables them to work and prepare for their future together.

Jennifer operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5-pesos-worth of cooking oil, or an egg.

Jennifer earns by buying supplies at the wholesale price and selling retail in small quantities. Her store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, Jennifer is requesting a Php 10,000 loan that she will use to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. She has been a member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* for almost two years now.
 
Jennifer dreams of having a successful and peaceful life. She also hopes that she will be having a comfortable and well-off future with all the hard work she puts into her business.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
A hardworking and die-hard agriculturalist, R. Wilson, aged 69 years, has been maintaining a banana plantation and rearing cows for more than thirty years in his home area of Ntungamo. This fetches him 160,000 Ugandan shillings per month from milk and banana sales, though not enough to sustain his family of ten children as some are still students attending high institutions of learning.

Wilson has persevered to keep his enterprise growing and his aim in taking up this loan is to enable him to buy mulches and manure for his plantations as he looks at expansion plans of starting up a poultry project, and transporting his products to bigger markets. This will help him increase productivity and also earn more revenue and be able to live a more sustaining life.

Before indulging in business, Wilson was a Clerical Officer in Ruhaama until he inherited the current business from his late father. However, he has worked hard to make the business better.

loans.use: To purchase mulches and manure for his plantation and to start a poultry project

loans.name: Luvsantseren

texts.en:
Luvsantseren S. is 61 years old and lives with his wife and four children in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city Mongolia. His children range in age from 21 to 33 years and they help out with their parents' business. He lives with her wife in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, while the children live in houses separately in the same yard.

Luvsantseren began his business in 1993 specializing in the sale of electric cable, accessories, tires and other electrical stuff. He sells at three rented stalls in Narantuul, the biggest and most crowded market in Ulaanbaatar. He says, “My only wish is to complete the new house which is under construction now”.

Luvsantseren is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan in order to increase his business working capital and purchase more electrical stuff and items at wholesale prices to retail in his business.

loans.use: To purchase more electrical stuff to sell

loans.name: Shamim Begum's Group

texts.en:
Shamim Begum is a wife of A. D.. They reside in a city in Pakistan called Multan, which is famous for its history and warm weather. Her husband is involved in the boutique business. He displays his handmade dresses with different designs in his boutique. To complete the dresses, Shamim also supports him so he is able to display new designs of clothes and attract more customers. 
 
He started this business a few years ago from savings and started earning well. Basically, his boutique is placed in a market that is always filled with heavy crowds and being a part of that place, he has to keep his boutique up-to-date with the latest fashions in clothes. 
 
Therefore, Shamim has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s boutique. With the loan amount, he will buy items such as cloth, beads, laces and tassels in bulk, which will enable him to make more dresses to display in his boutique.
 
She is very much hopeful that this investment will prove best for her husband’s business. He will be able to generate good profit on it and improve the living standard of the family.

loans.use: Purchase the required items in bulk for boutique business

loans.name: Bushura Tutungukye, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Patrick B., aged 35, is married with a family of four children. He has been operating a retail shop from the Bushura trading center in Kihihi for over 15 years. In here, he trades in a variety of products commonly for domestic use like sugar, salt, soft drinks (sodas, water), cooking oil and much more general merchandise. He does this business alongside his other farming practices that include growing a variety of food crops in Uganda. 

His main drawback is that he has a limited variety of products in his shop that cannot satisfy the customers' demand. Therefore, Patrick is looking forward to increasing stock in his business when he gets this loan, and also expanding into a wholesale shop. This will help him earn more revenue and sustain his daily life needs and further educate his children. 

He also belongs to a group of members who insure each other in paying back the loan.

loans.use: Purchase more stock for the shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Samir

texts.ru:
Samir A. 43 let. On yavlyayetsya  Samir pereselenec in Fuzuli , seychas on projivayet v Fuzuli regione, . On jenat i imeyet 3 detey , sin 17 let kotoriy uchitsya v shkole i xodit na shaxmati , dochka kotoroy 13 let ona toje uchitsya v shkole  i zanimayetsya tancami i dochka 9 let kotoraya xodit v shkolu i ochen lubit uchitsya. 

Samir uje 3 let kak otkril etot maqazin i rabotayet v nem. Etomu biznesu eqo naushil starshiy brat. Seychas Samir nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit produkti  dlya pereprodaji.
texts.en:
Samir A. is forty-three years old and lives in the Fuzuli region. He has three children: A seventeen-year-old son, who enjoys playing chess, and two daughters, thirteen and seven. The former is an avid dancer, while the latter likes going to school. Three years ago, Samir opened a store. He learned the bussiness from his brother. Now Samir needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy foodstuffs for resale.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Simon Mpayiani

texts.en:
Simon Mpayiani T. is a 28-year-old single man.  He is a farmer, and has been farming on his own piece of land for the last seven years. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his goals.

This will be Simon’s first loan with KADET.  He learned about KADET through a friend who is already a registered member. Simon is planning to spend ten thousand on ploughing, ten thousand on harrowing, five thousand on seeds, and five thousand on planting five acres of wheat. His dream is do large-scale farming, buy a bigger piece of land and attain financial independence. He hopes to use the profits generated from this loan to take the first step toward achieving this dream by expanding his farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming.

loans.use: to plough and harrow his soil, and to buy and plant seeds

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra is a 40-year-old married woman who lives in Multan, a city in Pakistan famous for its history and warm weather.  She is an uneducated woman who couldn’t attend school due to her family’s poor financial condition. She spent lots of time with her mother when she was young, and helped her cook food and handle domestic chores.  

Azra learned how to manage a household efficiently from her mother, a very patient lady who knew how to control and meet expenses. She learned patience from her mother, and now she handles her own expenses as her mother would have, but the circumstances have entirely changed due to inflation and other economic conditions. She still tries to manage things, though it is very difficult. Azra’s husband, N., respects her for this wonderful habit.  

N. has a shawl-selling business, which he purchased in his native city of Multan. He purchases the shawls cheaply and sells them for a good profit. His earnings help Azra to meet the financial expenses of the family. Azra has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband, which he will use to buy shawls in bulk and expand his business. She hopes that purchasing shawls in bulk will help him to reduce his travelling expenses and improve his earnings, and allow him to save something for a rainy day.

loans.use: to purchase shawls for reselling

loans.name: Esenali

texts.en:
Esenali Y. is a resident of Kadamjai, a nice town in the south of Kyrgyzstan.  He is 45 years old, married, and has four children: two sons and two daughters. The first son and the first daughter are engaged in farming and the other children go to school.  In 1995, when the collective farms broke up, Esenali got a plot of land and he started to grow rice. He now also breeds cattle, and by selling it after it has been fattened he makes 8000 soms per month. With his loan Esenali wants to purchase 1.5 tons of mineral fertilizer for growing rice. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds a triple bottom line: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (remaining environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team: Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Richard Oino

texts.en:
Richard Oino K. is 37 years old. He is married to Rispah K. and a father of three school age children. He has a cereal store business that he has been running for the last 10years on a busy street in Narok Town. He learned about KADET through a friend who is a KADET registered client. This will be his fourth loan, which he is planning to use to increase his stock of maize. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to open another shop and create employment for other people. Also this being the peak season for harvesting maize and wheat, he is hoping to buy more stock to sell later when the price and demand are high.

His future dream is that he will be able to build his own store and house. 

Richard also believes he is hard working and he only needs the resources to attain his goals.

loans.use: To increase his stock of maize.

loans.name: Kochkorbai

texts.en:
Kochkorbai N. is a resident of Kadamjai, a nice town on the south of Kyrgyzstan.  Kochkorbai is 49 and married. He has four sons and a daughter. The two older sons are engaged in farming, the third son is a musician, the daughter is at school and the fourth son is a newborn. Kochkorbai has been growing rice since 1995. By selling some of the harvest, he makes 5,500 soms per month. That profit made it possible for him to purchase cattle, repair the house and purchase a vehicle. With the money received from the loan, Kochkorbai wants to purchase one ton of mineral fertilizers for growing rice. In the near future, he plans to celebrate his older son’s wedding.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.
1102-016507-01

loans.use: To purchase mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Marasua  Ole

texts.en:
Marasua Ole N. is 52 years old. He is married to Musul N. and a father of two school-going children. Marasua is a farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land. He has been farming for the last ten years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who is a KADET registered client in his area of residence. This will be his first loan, which he is planning to spend as follows:  15,000 on harrowing, 10,000 on seeds and 5,000 on planting his five-acre wheat farm.

He is anticipating ploughing more land for wheat with the profit from his expanded farming activity.

He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: Harrowing, seeds and planting

loans.name: Baktygul

texts.en:
Baktygul K. is the resident of Kadamjai, a nice town in the south of Kyrgyzstan.  Baktygul is 31 and married. She has a daughter and two sons; all of them are at school. Two years ago, with the initial investment of 15,000 soms, Baktygul started to sell convenience goods. In this way, she makes 6,000 soms per month.  This autumn, Baktygul wants to try to sell school uniforms, so with money received from the loan she wants to purchase school uniforms and resell them at a higher price. In the future, she is planning to build a shop in her village. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase school uniforms

loans.name: Francis Matambash

texts.en:
Francis Matambash K. is 23 years old. He is a single young man who is practicing farming.

Francis is a farmer and he does the farming on his father’s piece of land, which he has been doing for the last two years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who is already a registered member in KADET. This will be his first loan. He is planning to spend 10,000 shillings on plowing, 10,000 on harrowing, 5,000 on seeds and 5,000 on planting 5 acres of wheat.

He hopes to use the profits from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming. Francis' dream is do large-scale farming, buy his own land and attain financial independence. 

He is a young, hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To plow, harrow, seed and plant 5 acres of wheat

loans.name: Dorlig

texts.en:
Mr. Dorlig is 46 years old and lives with his wife and five sons in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They all live together in a small house that they built recently. His eldest son is married but still lives in father’s house. His three younger sons, Chimiddorj, Turbold and Cagaancooj, are in high school and secondary school. 

Dorlig runs a taxi business in the city in his own car, which he bought on leasing contract from his taxi company. He enjoys transporting people. He also works in a secondary school as a carpenter and plumber on a part-time basis. Dorlig is a very hardworking person and is known for his good character. He has gained a lot of experience over the years and is a trusted driver for his many customers. 

Last April, Dorlig took a loan from Kiva, used it appropriately and paid back in full, on time. Now he is requesting a loan for the second time to complete his house improvement.

loans.use: To complete his house renovation

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en: Loreta I. is from the village of Kabuhi, Pandan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old. Loreta is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Loreta makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling specialty foods for meals, like papaya salad and jackfruit salad. Loreta has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Loreta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Loreta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Loreta is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional ingredients and as working capital. This will be the third loan taken out by Loreta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients and as working capital

loans.name: Ireneo

texts.en:
This is Ireneo C., 60,a resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Jocelyn, a beautician, and father to three young adults.

Ireneo operates a van for rent business. As many Filipinos do not own their own private vehicle, commuting is the main way of transportation. It would, however, be inappropriate for occasions like weddings, personal weekend jaunts, or where people need the services of their own vehicle. This is where Ireneo’s business steps in. Vehicles are rented out by the day or by the hour. Ireneo also owns a used clothing store. Called “ukay-ukay”( because these clothing would be displayed bunched up in huge mounds, and people would dig for their choices in the vast clothing varieties. “Ukay” comes from the Tagalog word “hukay” basically meaning to dig out. It is a very popular way to buy imported and branded clothing for almost 90% off the price.)

To help him continue operating his business, he is requesting a PHP 11,000 loan. He will be using the loan to buy more quantities of products to be incorporated into his current inventory. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business. He has been a member of Center for Community Transformation for three years now and is regularly attending fellowship meeting*.
  
Ireneo dreams of having a happy future with his wife and his family. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products to be incorporated into his current inventory

loans.name: Merlina

texts.en:
Merlina E. is from the village of Pinoma, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 53 years old. Merlina is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Merlina owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Merlina has been engaged in her business for over three years and she want to start up her business again. Her previous income was 3,000 PHP per month. 

In 2007, Merlina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Merlina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: William Kabaka

texts.en:
William Kabaka K. is 31 years old. He is a farmer and supports five people in his family. His spouse is Nolari Kabaka and they have two children aged five years and one years old.  Nolari is a housewife and she helps William in his farming activity.

William has been doing wheat farming for the last eight years. This will be his first loan and he is planning to use it to prepare his five-acre farm for planting. He is planning to use the anticipated profit from his farming to expand his farming activity by renting a bigger piece of land to increase his wheat production. His hopes and dreams are to become a large-scale farmer owning a bigger piece of land and be financially stable to support his family. 

He is hardworking and optimistic towards achieving his set target.

loans.use: To prepare his farm for planting.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita O. is from the village of Maranding, Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 45 years old, widowed and has 7 school-aged children. Teresita owns and operates a specialized retail store,  selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional fish to sell. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to increase working capital. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Teresita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and to increase working capital

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena M. is from the village of San Pablo, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 42 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. Elena owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Elena is just starting this business.

In 2010, Elena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elena is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and build a permanent pig shelter. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Elena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and build a permanent pig shelter

loans.name: Lenkoti Ole

texts.en:
Lenkoti Ole N. is 25 years old. He is married to Kijoli N. and is the father of three children. Lenkoti has been farming on his own piece of land for the last four years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who is a KADET registered client in his area of residence. This will be his first loan. He is planning to spend 15,000 KES on harrowing, 15,000 KES on seeds and 10,000 KES on planting his wheat farm. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to reinvest in the farm and plant a bigger piece of land with wheat. Lenkoti's dream is to do large scale farming, attain financial independence and buy his own farm machinery. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: to buy seeds and to harrow and plant his wheat farm

loans.name: Nassim

texts.en: Nassim is a 32-year-old married man from Lebanon. He has been working in construction as an aluminum expert for 15 years. Nassim sells aluminum doors, windows, kitchens and closets. He was very young when he started to learn this business; it was the family’s needs that drove him to work in order to help his parents earn an income. And he became an expert in his field. This is the first time that Nassim is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, in order to buy necessary material for his business. With this loan, Nassim believes he will be able to expand his work and become well known among competitors, which will increase his income and help in providing a secure life for his family.

loans.use: To buy necessary material for his business

loans.name: Metekai Ole

texts.en:
Metekai Ole K. is 39 years old. He is married to Kirotian K. and is the father of three school-aged children. Metekai has been farming on his own piece of land for the last ten years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who is a KADET registered client in his area of residence. This will be his first loan. He is planning to spend 15,000 KES on harrowing, 15,000 KES on seed and 10,000 KES on planting his five acre wheat farm. He anticipates to buy some farm machinery with the profits from the expanded farming activity. 

He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To buy seeds and to harrow and plant his five acre wheat farm

loans.name: Aladdin

texts.ru:
Aladdin S. yavlyayetsya  on pereselenec iz Fuzuli, seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione. Alladdin  Shirinovu 42 qoda. On jenat i imeyet 2 detey, Sin 16 let uchitsya v shkole i sin 15 let kotoriy uchisya toje v shkole i zanimayetsya sportom. 

Aladdin uje 6 let zanimayetsya skotovodstvom. Etomu biznesu on nauchilsya u svoyeqo dyadi  kotoriy imeyet mnoqo skota. Seychas Aladdin nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit   samku tak kak u neqo imeyetsya samec.
texts.en:
Aladdin S. is a refugee from Fuzuli who now lives in the Fuzuli region. Aladdin S. is 42 years old. He is married and has two children. His sixteen-year-old son goes to school, and his fifteen-year-old son goes to school and plays sports. Aladdin has been a herdsman for six years. He started in this business with his uncle who has many head of cattle. Now, Aladdin needs 2000 AZN to buy a cow since he already has a bull.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy calves

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily A., 60, lives in Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Jose A., a tricycle driver, and is the mother of five children, all of whom are already working.

Emily operates a variety store while overseeing operations of their computer rental shop. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP worth of cooking oil or an egg. Emily earns her income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at a piece rate. Emily’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in daily sales.

To help her continue operating her business, Emily is requesting a PHP 18,000 loan. She will use the loan to expand her product inventory of groceries, toiletries and beverages. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Emily has been a member of Center for Community Transformation for 3 years now and regularly attends fellowship meetings. Emily dreams of being able to help others from her blessings from the Lord.

loans.use: to expand her product inventory of groceries, toiletries and beverages

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
Zubaida is a 40-year-old married woman who lives in the city of Multan, Pakistan, famous for its history and warm weather. Her husband is a private entrepreneur who deals in clothing, selling it to different areas of the community. Zubaida stays at home, manages the household chores and takes care of her family. She also helps her husband in arranging the clothes in his bicycle to make it easier for him to display his merchandise. 
 
Zubaida's husband attracts people by making loud announcements about his product. He works 7-10 hours daily, which makes him tired enough. That’s why Zubaida has applied for a loan from Asasah. She will invest the loan amount in her husband’s business so he would be able to buy clothing in bulk and supply it to clothing stores without having to travel to different communities to sell his merchandise. She is hopeful that, in this way, her husband may increase his income and be able to work on a larger scale.

loans.use: to buy clothing to resell

loans.name: Fatmeh

texts.en: Fatima is a a 33-year-old married woman who lives in Bint Jbeil, Lebanon with her husband and four children. Fatima has owned a clothing shop since 2008; she has worked in other shops since 2003. As she worked hard to establish her own business, cash flow was the major problem delaying the achievement of her goal. This is Fatima’s first time requesting a loan from Al Majmoua since she would like to support her business before the coming Holy Ramadan season and the new autumn collection. Fatima sells clothes, lingerie and perfumes in her store. She believes that a good business must contain as much as the client needs. Fatima works hard to help her husband in raising their four children the best way they can, providing them with education, good living and respect.

loans.use: To support her business

loans.name: Khristine

texts.en:
Khristine D. is from the village of Brgy. Escoting, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 25 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Khristine owns and operates a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Khristine has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Khristine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Khristine is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Khristine from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Gulzat's Group

texts.en: Gulzat A. is the leader of the group. She is 32 and married. She has two daughters and two sons. The older son and the older daughter are at school, but the other children are not yet. Gulzat's husband is the driver of an excavating machine and he earns 12000 soms per month. Three years ago with that money, Gulzat purchased livestock and then resold the livestock at a higher price. She made 15000 soms and since that moment, she has been breeding livestock. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase sheep for breeding. Gulzat is pregnant and in the near future they will have another child, so they are planning to start building a new house. Eliza T., 24, is married. She has two children, both of them are preschool age (under 7). Two years ago, with the initial investment of 30000 soms, Eliza and her husband started to breed livestock. Selling some livestock after fattening, they make 5000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for them to improve their living conditions and purchase a new fridge. With money received from the loan, Eliza wants to purchase sheep in order to increase the number of livestock they have. In the future, she is planning to start repairing her house. Ularkan J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 55 and a widow. She has raised nine children; two of them are at school and live with Ularkan. Two years ago, with the initial investment of 10000 soms, Ularkan started to purchase fruits and vegetables in the village and then resell them at the market at a higher price. In this way, she makes 10000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase a variety of fruits and vegetables in order to increase the turnover of her business. Gulmira T., 35, is married. She has two daughters and two sons. The older daughter and the older son are at school and the other children are not yet. Gulmira is engaged in cattle breeding; she resells cattle after fattening at a higher price. In this way, she makes 10000 soms per month. Her husband works as a driver, and when he is free, he helps his wife with her activity. Gulmira applied for the loan because she needs money to finish building her house. In the future, she wants to build a shop and start selling convenience goods. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase sheep for breeding

loans.name: Meiseiyieki Ole

texts.en: Meiseiyieki Ole M. is 50 years old and has four children with his wife, Nashuluni M.. For the last 15 years, he has made a living as a farmer, and recently learned about KADET through a friend who is one of our clients. He is applying for his first loan, which he will use to plant a new wheat crop and improve his farm. He plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to bring more land into cultivation. In the future, his dream is to plant an even larger crop, become financially independent and buy his own equipment. Meiseiyieki is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his goals.

loans.use: To expand and improve his farm

loans.name: Hazaa

texts.en: Hazaa is 38 years old and lives in Bint Jbeil with his wife and six children. He has made a living raising sheep for the last 25 years, and has been self-employed since 1990. Hazaa has applied for a loan from Al Majmoua, his first, to buy a cow. This will allow him to increase his income by selling milk and raising calves. He loves his work a lot and believes that it's a good source for income for taking care of his family. In the future, he also hopes to own a large farm.

loans.use: To buy a cow so he can raise calves and sell its milk

loans.name: Haseena's Group

texts.en:
Haseena is a very talented woman who earns a living by making and selling shawls in the Pakistani city of Multan, which is famous for its history and warm weather. She is 38 years old, married and has lived in Multan for the last 15 years. She started her business five years ago to help her husband in his business, which also consists of selling shawls. Now they both do the same work but in different areas -- her husband sells in big cities such as Islamabad and Lahore, while she sells locally. 
 
Haseena has applied for a loan from Asasah to buy more shawls to sell to her customers. She also leads the five-person loan group whose members we see here. Her goal is to improve her family's living standards and, over time, expand her small business into a large one.

loans.use: To buy shawls to resell to her customers

loans.name: Tsendjav

texts.en: Tsendjav J. is 58 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Hovd province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent. Her wife is retired and his children work for a construction company. Since 2005, Tsendjav has made a living growing vegetables and now runs a stable business. He plants his crop in two places -- around his house, and on a separate piece of land outside of town. He and his family are repairing their house with some of the money he earns from his business. He hopes to use his future earnings to buy more land and plant more vegetables. Tsendjav is seeking a loan for 1,500,000 MNT to harvest his crop in the coming fall season.

loans.use: To harvest his crop

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
Philip M. lives the village of Brgy. Escoting, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 29 years old, married and has two school-aged children. He makes a living raising pigs and other livestock. He has been in this line of work for more than five years, and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

Earlier this year, Philip joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his life and ability to engage in business. He is applying for a 5,000 PHP loan, his first, to buy more livestock to raise. He plans to use the additional revenue generated by his business to improve his family's living standards. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy more livestock to raise

loans.name: Margaret  Naanyu

texts.en:
Margaret Naanyu K. is 33 years old. She is single and the mother of two children, 2 and 6 years old. Margaret has been farming on her own piece of land for the last ten years.
  
Margaret learned about KADET from a colleague who is already a KADET registered client. This will be her first loan. She is planning to spend 20,000 KES to buy chemicals and fertilizers for sukumawiki (green leafy vegetables) which she has already planted and 30,000 KES to prepare land to plant more vegetables. With the profits she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, she plans to reinvest in the farm and plant different varieties of vegetables such as cabbages, carrots, and spinach. Her hope and dream is to become a large scale vegetable farmer and to start fruit farming. Margaret is a hardworking woman and, with the right resources, she can do great.

loans.use: to buy chemicals and fertilizers for sukumawiki which she has already planted and to prepare land to plant more vegetables

loans.name: Ireneo's Group

texts.en:
Ireneo V. Jr. is from the village of Barikir, Yeban Norte. He is 26 years old. Ireneo is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Ireneo V. Jr.

Ireneo is single. To make a living, Ireneo owns & operates a business venture raising pigs for fattening and sale. Ireneo has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ireneo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ireneo is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ireneo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

location.town: Barikir, Yeban Norte, Benito Soliven, Isabela

loans.name: 02.01.15 Group

texts.en:
Nhu H. T. (51) is a 61-year-old femaL. living in the town of Thieu Hoa Thanh Hoa.  Nhu is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 15 (02.01.15).


Nhu is married and has three adult children.  To make a living, Nhu operates a family member's business raising cattL. for saL..  Nhu has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2006, Nhu joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Nhu has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 4,248,000 VND, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  The loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Nhu from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Nhu plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  L. T. Oanh (10) is a 36-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


2.  T. T. De (25) is a 34-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


3.  H. T. Hoi (39) is a 27-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Nhu H. T. (51) là 61 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thieu Hoa Thanh Hoa.  Nhu là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 15 (02.01.15).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  Nhu thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 15 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Nhu kiếm được khoảng 2.000.000 VND.  Vào 2006, Nhu đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Nhu đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.079.800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 4.248.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 12th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  L. T. oanh (10) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  T. T. de (25) là 34 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


3.  H. T. Hoi (39) là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: Olonana  Ole

texts.en:
Olonana Ole L. is 31 years old. He is married to Noormeiseer L. and the father of three children. Olonana and his wife are farmers and they have been doing farming activity on their own piece of land for the last 10 years.
  
He learned about KADET from a colleague who is already a KADET registered client. This will be his second loan. He is planning to spend 30,000 shillings to buy chemicals and fertilizers for tomatoes, which he has already planted. He will spend the remaining 20,000 shillings to prepare land to plant more tomatoes .This area has favorable climatic condition for tomato farming, which is why he has been doing tomato farming successfully for many years. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to re-invest in the farm and plow a bigger piece of land to plant more.

His hope and dream is to become a large scale farmer and own some farm machinery to make his farming work easy.

He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and fertilizers and to prepare the land to plant more tomatoes

loans.name: Munhtuul

texts.en: Munhtuul A. lives with her daughter and parents in Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her parents are retired and her only daughter attends the 87th secondary school of Bayanzurh district in their town.  Munhtuul operates a snuff bottle retailing business at Naraantuul, the biggest and most crowded market in Ulaanbaatar city. She began her business in 2000 and since then she has gained many skills and much experience in her operation. Munhtuul purchases snuff bottles in bulk in Ereen, the border city of Mongolia, once a month. The products she imports are the various stones with snuff bottle shapes. She assembles and makes the head of the snuff bottle herself by hand, which has to be matched to its main body. Munhtuul manages her assembly process in her small crafts shop. The most profitable season for her business is during Mongolian Traditional Lunar New Year and most of her purchasers and clients are the people who arrive from the countryside.  Munhtuul is a creative and skilled woman who works hard to afford her daughter's education expenses and wishes her daughter to enter a university and obtain a good education. In the near future, Munhtuul hopes to create a new workplace and begin crafting a wider variety of jewelry products. As the busy fall season is underway in Mongolia, Munhtuul needs to purchase more raw materials to produce snuff bottles. She is requesting a 1,340,000 MNT loan in order to increase her working capital for her business.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Kasaine

texts.en:
Kasaine K. is 24 years old. He is married to Noomechuki K. and the father of one child who is one year old. Kasaine is a farmer and he has been farming on his own piece of land for the last four years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who is a KADET registered client in his area of residence. This will be his first loan, which he is planning to spend as follows: 20,000 KES on harrowing,15,000 KES on seeds and 15,000 KES on planting his wheat farm.

He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming by plowing a bigger piece of land for planting wheat. Kasaine's dreams are to do large scale farming, attain financial independence and buy his own farm machinery. 

He is a young, hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: For harrowing, purchasing seeds and planting his wheat farm.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita A. is from the village of Brgy. Aggub, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 44 years old. Anita is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Anita owns & operates a business selling fruits and vegetables in the local community. Anita has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Anita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Anita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Shiinka Ole

texts.en:
Shiinka Ole P. is 31 years old. He is married to Nalotuesha and is a father of four children. He does cattle rearing, which he has been doing for the last eight years. His target is to buy young heifers during dry season when they are not very costly, then place them on his farm, which he has fenced purposely for grazing. After the rainy season when the bulls have fattened, he sells them at a higher price and earns some profit.

He learned about KADET from marketing awareness done by KADET staffs in his area. This will be his first loan. He is planning to use the proceeds of the loan to buy five more young bulls for fattening to sell latter at a profit.

With the anticipated profit, he intends to acquire a bigger piece of land and fence it for grazing. His future dream is that he will become a large-scale farmer in cattle rearing. 

He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To buy five young heifers for fattening at 10,000 shillings each.

loans.name: Nergui

texts.en:
Nergui O. is 42 years old and lives with her husband and four children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Hovd province in western Mongolia. Her younger two children attend a local middle school while the elder two children help out with their family business. Nergui works in a small underground water well, delivering water to local people. 

Her husband has been engaging in ironsmithing for 25 years in his town and has gained much experience in the business. Now he is teaching and instructing his son how to process iron and make quality products. 

For the future, Nergui's dream is to buy a large amount of stock in order to increase her business line, and to save money for her youngest children's further education fees and expenses. 

Nergui and her husband are both hardworking people. She is requesting a 1,800,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase precious stones, jewelries, gold and silver in order to produce rings, earrings, snuff bottles and horse bridles for their business.

loans.use: To purchase precious stones, jewleries, gold and silver

loans.name: Dana

texts.en:
Dana is a 36-year-old married woman and mother of four children. She has been working with handcrafts and planting tobacco since 2003. This is the first time Dana requests a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy important materials for her handcrafts work and to start a new trading business to increase her family’s income. 

Dana’s work is well-known among her neighbors and relatives and her business is becoming wider; that’s why she is working hard on staying up to date with what’s in the market. She believes in working hard to provide a secure living and education for her children. She hopes to open an atelier (workshop or studio) to put in all her handcrafts so everyone can visit and see her work.

loans.use: To buy important materials for handcrafts

loans.name: Silole  Ene

texts.en:
Silole Ene S. is 41years old and she supports six members of her family. She has been wheat farming for the last three years successfully; this has been due to good climatic conditions and a ready market for the produce in her area.
 
This being her first loan, she is planning to spend 20,000 shillings on harrowing, 15,000 to buy wheat seeds, fertilizer and chemicals, and the remaining 15,000 on planting.

Her plan for the anticipated profits is that she will expand her wheat farm to large-scale farming. Her hopes and dreams are that she will become a large-scale farmer and be able to educate her kids to higher levels of education.

She is a hardworking woman and determined to achieve her set target.

loans.use: To harrow; buy wheat seeds, fertilizer and chemicals; and plant wheat

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
The mankousheh is a typical Lebanese snack: Baked in a very special way, this unique sandwich usually contains hand-made thyme or fresh melted cheese. Tomatoes, pickles and fresh mint leaves are sometimes added to complete the masterpiece. This is why everyone, from the richest rich to the beggar in the street, eats this mouth-watering snack. Served as breakfast, lunch or dinner, the mankousheh is light on the stomach and on the pocket. In fact, this sandwich has become a symbol of the Lebanese national identity. It must be as old as the culture since no one knows when it was invented, but everyone has tasted it and loved it. So this is partly why the Lebanese abroad miss three things only: their homes, their family and the mankousheh. 

So as a 45-year-old married man with three children and as an owner of a mankousheh bakery, Ali is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to increase the business’ capital, and to buy necessary gas and flour to keep this mankousheh in its royal place. 

This is his third time to request a loan from Al Majmoua, and he proved to be a person in good standing. He hopes to expand his bakery in the future and open another one.

loans.use: To increase business capital

loans.name: Karanja Ole

texts.en:
Karanja Ole S. is 41 years old. He is married to Sempeta S. and he is the father of two children. Karanja is a farmer and he has been doing the farming on his own piece of land for the last 10 years.

He learned about KADET from marketing awareness done by KADET staff in his area. This will be his first loan. He is planning to spend the 50,000 shillings to prepare his land for planting wheat, which has proved to be doing very well due to favorable climatic conditions. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to plow more land for farming to increase his wheat production. 

His future dream is that he will become a large-scale wheat farmer in his area. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: He is planning to spend 50,000 shillings to prepare land for planting wheat

loans.name: Agnes Bosibori

texts.en:
Agnes Bosibori M. is 26 years old. She is married and the mother of two children; one is 5 years old and the other is 5 months old. She has a small shop that she has been running for the last four years on a busy street in Narok Town.

She learned about KADET from other women who are already registered as clients. This will be her second loan. She is planning to increase her shop stock by buying more soft drinks, especially during this sunny season as she knows demand for them will be high. With the profits she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, she plans to open another shop and create employment for other people. 

Her future dream is that she will be able to build her own house and be running the shop at her own premises.
 
Agnes also believes she is hardworking and she only needs the resources to attain her goals.

loans.use: To increase her shop stock by buying more soft drinks

loans.name: Narantsetseg

texts.en:
Narantsetseg P. is a 43-year-old widow who lives with her three children in Hovd province, western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her elder child is a student while the younger two children attend a local middle school. 

Her husband passed away recently, in April 2010, and since then, Narantsetseg has been trying her best to provide her children with their necessities. She began her clothing retailing business in 2003 out of a stall in a local market and has been able to increase her family’s earnings. Her business has stabilized over the past years and she has begun to integrate herself into the business community. 

Narantsetseg is a modest and hardworking woman who is requesting a 2,000,000 Mongolian tugriks loan in order to purchase a large amount of a variety of clothing and a wide number of household items for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of clothing

loans.name: Nurgul's Group

texts.en:
Nurgul M. is the leader of the group. She is 29 and married. She has three daughters, all of them are preschool age (under 7).  

Nurgul works as a teacher and her husband is a constructor. In order to make money, Nurgul and her husband breed livestock. They have been doing it for five years. Sometimes they sell some animals to cover family expenses. With money received from the loan, Nurgul wants to improve her living conditions and purchase a fridge. In the future, she plans to increase the number of livestock they have and start repairing her house.

Kokon J., 48, is a widow. She has raised six children; the younger son and the younger daughter are at school and the others are working, married and live separately with their families. Kokon applied for the loan because she needs money to celebrate her son’s wedding. 

Burmakan K. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 54 and a widow. She has raised eight children, most of them live separately, except the youngest daughter, who is at school. Four years ago, Burmakan sold three sheep and with that money, she started to sell convenience goods. In this way, she earns 5000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase sheep to increase the number of livestock and with the rest of the money, she will purchase a variety of goods to increase the turnover of her business. In the future, she plans to start repairing her house.

Imarathan D., 55, is a widow. She has raised five children, four of them are at school. Eight years ago, with the initial investment of 26000 soms, Imarathan started to sell convenience goods. She makes 10000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase a variety of goods to increase the turnover of her business. 

Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 \

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a fridge

loans.name: Patrick Ndungu

texts.en:
Patrick Ndungu G. is 41 years old and he supports a family of four. His spouse is Jane Muthoni, who is a businesswoman contributing an income of 24,000 shillings per month.

Patrick is a businessman running a spare-part shop in Narok town. He sells spare parts of different vehicle models, and his regular customers are motor vehicle mechanics from the Narok Motor garage, which is located next to his shop. He has been in this business for the last four years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who is already a registered member in KADET. This will be his first loan, which he is planning to use to buy more spare parts to increase his stock.

He hopes to use the anticipated profit from this loan to expand his business and open up another spare-part shop.

Patrick’s dream is to become a wholesaler and be the spare-part distributor in Narok town.

He is a hardworking man with a great vision.

loans.use: To buy more vehicle spare parts, especilly for Toyota saloon cars.

loans.name: Nurzada

texts.en:
Nurzada K. is 34 years old.  She graduated from medical college and currently works as a medical dispatcher at Talas State Transport Station. Her colleagues characterize her as a very optimistic and responsible person. Nurzada has three children: a daughter who is 15 and two sons, 9 and 2 years old.  Her husband works as a taxi driver. 

The salary of medical personnel is low and earnings from taxi transportation cannot cover family expenses.  For this reason, Nurzada started her own businesses: cattle breeding and cultivating kidney beans and perennial herbs. Using the amount of 7,000 Kyrgyz Soms to purchase one calf and plant seeds, Nurzada got started and worked hard to make her business successful.  Today, Nurzada has one milk cow and ten sheep. Using the revenue from reselling fattened livestock and from her harvest, she was able to buy a used car for her family. 

Nurzada plans to use this loan of 70,000 Kyrgyz Soms to broaden her business by purchasing 20 sheep. With the revenue from this investment, Nurzada plans to buy bull-calves for fattening. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase 20 sheep

loans.name: Jean Nepomuscene

texts.en:
J. Nepomuscene is a young man who is 23 years of age. He owns a retail shop that sells all types of drinks and he has done this business for four years.

He expects to broaden his inventory with this loan by buying more groceries for sale. This will lead to the accumulation of profits and, according to him, it will enable him to increase his savings. J. Nepomuscene loves his profession and he has a dream of raising his capital from both the loan and his savings to RWF 2,000,000 (approx. $3,400). He believes this can occur with the profits he generates from hard work.

loans.use: Buying more grocery items for sale
