loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Mrs. Pen S. has spent her life farming crops — a skill she learned from her grandparent when she was young. She is now married and has five children: one is already married and lives independently, while the other four are single. Her husband, shown in the photograph, frequently works in the farm fields alongside her. She has had great success in raising crops. The couple is able to plant crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. The coming rainfall is good for growing but Pen S. doesn’t have the necessary capital so is looking for a loan to use to plant rice.

loans.use: To use to plant rice.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “VAMOS JUNTOS”; La socia esta ubicada en el barrio de Arcopata, perteneciente al distrito de Santiago , provincia y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Arlene; ella tiene 27 años de edad y es conviviente y  tiene 2 Hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el comercio minorista, Ella se dedica a la compra y venta de habas y también de cds los fines de semana; La socia es una mujer pujante y llena de muchas sueños y poco a  poco los ira cumpliendo, por lo pronto ella comprara mercadería en cuanto a sus cds y comprara habas a los productores de este producto. La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de habas y en la compra de cds.

La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our associate is a part of the “Vamos Juntos” (We Go Together) communal bank. She lives in the Arcopata neighborhood, within the Santiago province, in the Cusco department. Arlene is 27 years old, lives with her life partner and has two children. She has a small business where she buys and sells beans. She also sells CDs on the weekend. She is a dynamic woman, full of many dreams, which she’s been achieving little by little. She will use the money from this loan to buy more CDs and will also buy beans from the local farmers. She is grateful to those who form part of this dream through this medium and she is committed to making her payments on schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Guido

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal “VAMOS JUNTOS”; El socio está ubicada en el barrio de Arcopata, perteneciente al distrito de Santiago, provincia y departamento de Cusco.

El socio es la Sr. Guido; el tiene 30  años de edad y es conviviente y  tiene 2 Hijos; El socio alterna sus actividades diarias con el trabajo de construcción, el socio es obrero y realiza obras, en esta oportunidad el socio quiere comprar un pequeño terreno, para lo cual ha estado juntando y este préstamo le ayudara a completar la cantidad que necesita. El socio es solicita el préstamo para invertir en comprar un terreno.

El socio agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The member belongs to communal bank "Vamos Juntos" (Together we go); he lives in the neighborhood Arcopata, which belongs to the Santiago district, and Cusco province.

The member is Mr. Guido; he is 30 years old, lives with his partner, and has two children. He alternates his daily work between construction work and is a worker in a construction site. He would like to buy a small piece of land. He already has been saving and this loan will help him complete the remaining amount. The main reason he is requesting the loan is to buy land.

The member is thankful for the people that form a part of this dream by means of this resource and commits to carry out the scheduled loan payments.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Garza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of land.

loans.name: Karen Rossmery

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “VAMOS JUNTOS”; La socia esta ubicada en el barrio de Arcopata, perteneciente al distrito de Santiago , provincia y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Karen; ella tiene 40  años de edad y es conviviente y  tiene 3 Hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con la capacitación en gestión empresarial que está dictando una municipalidad a la que ella se inscribió, este curso de capacitación les enseña a producir en el caso de la socia en especifico los derivados de la leche, ella está produciendo, quesos y yogurt, mantequilla. La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de insumos para poner en práctica lo aprendido y generar su propio negocio.

La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Karen belongs to the "Vamos Juntos" ("We Go Together") community bank and lives in the community of Arcopata, district of Santiago, province of Cusco, Peru. She is 40 years old, lives with her partner and has three children. She is currently taking business-management courses she signed up for through the city, and these courses are teaching her how to produce, specifically in Karen's case, dairy products. She has been producing cheeses, yogurt and butter. She is requesting the loan to purchase ingredients so she can put into practice what she has learned and start her own business. Karen is grateful for those who help her reach her dream through these means, and she promises to fulfill her payments in the established period.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make dairy products

loans.name: Ana Rocio

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “VAMOS JUNTOS”; La socia está ubicada en el barrio de Arcopata, perteneciente al distrito de Santiago, provincia y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Ana; ella tiene 20  años de edad y es conviviente y  tiene 1 Hijo; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el comercio minorista, Ella se dedica a elaboración y venta de chicha blanca de quinua y manzana, la socia genera su propio dinero con este su negocio, ella suele despertarse muy temprano y prepara su chicha de quinua con todos los ingredientes necesarios, sale de su casa a las 6 de la mañana y arma su stand en la esquina de su barrio, acompaña esta bebida un queque sabroso o sándwich diferentes; La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en comprar ingredientes .

La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Ana belongs to the "Vamos Juntos" ("We Go Together") community bank and lives in the community of Arcopata, district of Santiago, province of Cusco, Peru. She is 20 years old, lives with her partner and has one son. She makes a living as a commercial retailer, making and selling a liquor derived from quinoa and apples. She earns her own income from this business. She usually wakes up very early to prepare her drink, called chicha, with all the necessary ingredients. She leaves her home at 6 a.m. and sets up her stand at her neighborhood corner. She also sells tasty cakes or different sandwiches to accompany the beverage. She is requesting the loan to purchase ingredients. Ana is grateful for those who help her reach her dream through these means, and she promises to fulfill her payments in the established period.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make her products

loans.name: Rahbarjon

texts.ru: Айтматов Рахбарчон проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 30 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Рахбарчон не имеет высшего образования. Занимается торговлей на рынке. У него магазин, где он продает конфеты и печенья. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 2 года. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара, так как в сентябре спрос на его товар увеличится. Этим он сможет получить хорошую прибыль и удовлетворить свои потребности.
texts.en:
Rahbarjon Aymatov lives in the Hamadoni region. He is 30 years old. He is married and has three children. His wife is a homemaker. Rahbarjon does not have a high education. He sells on the market. He has a store where he sells candy and baked goods. He has been in this business for two years. He is taking out a loan to increase the variety of his inventory because the demand for his merchandise will increase in September. By this he make more a good profit and meet his needs.

Translated from Russian by Elena Bortnikoff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase inventory assortment

loans.name: Naseem Akhter

texts.en:
Naseem akhter lives in a small city called Borewala which is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan. She is a 46-year-old woman who has been living in Borewala with her family for the past 9 years. She is the mother of three sons; one of them is illiterate while other two are studying in 5th and 2nd class respectively.
 
She helps her family financially by selling clothes. She purchases clothes from Multan and sells them in the local market. Her husband is a cook by profession. He supplies food on order for marriage parties and functions. 

Her eldest son couldn’t study because he had to support his family financially so he started a motor workshop where he specializes in bike repair. His business is doing well but he needs to purchase some of the latest tools for making repairs. Therefore, Naseem has applied for a loan from Asasah to enable her son to buy the latest tools. She hopes that this investment will give her son’s business a profitable position.

Naseem is in her 3rd loan cycle. In the past loans she has maintained good credit and proven to be a responsible loan user for Asasah.

loans.use: Purchase latest repair tools for motor-workshop

loans.name: Nafees Akhter

texts.en:
Nafees akhter is a housewife who has been living in Borewala city with her husband and seven children for the past four years. 
She is 43 years old. She spends her time in her four room brick house and takes care of her household responsibilities. 
Her husband runs a canteen and her eldest son also helps him in his business. Her eldest son studied till 5th standard and left his education to support his family.
 
Nafees has four sons and three daughters. Her sons, except the eldest one, are getting their education and her three daughters are also attending school.
 
Nafees has applied for a loan from Asasah to support her husband who wants to expand his canteen business. With the loan amount her husband will buy food products, bottles, snacks, etc. for selling through his canteen. Nafees is hopeful that her husband will be able to improve his business with the help of this investment. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and has a good credit record. This is the third time she has applied for a loan.

loans.use: Purchase food products (bottles, snacks) for canteen business

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia M. is from the village of Lanna, Solana, Cagayan. She is 48 years old. Leticia is married and has five school-aged children. Leticia owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Leticia has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

Leticia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Leticia is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Leticia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: In

texts.en:
Sewing clothes is the main part of 22-year-old Mrs. In N.'s daily duty at the garment industry. In N. has been engaged in her job since 2008 and has a formal salary.

She has a life partner in her husband (pictured) who works in the construction field. The couple helps each other to earn money to feed their two kids. Both of the kids are attending school. 

In N. is concerned that she faces difficulties in travelling to her workplace. She and her husband always travel to work by hiring a taxi or walking because they don't have their own vehicle. To solve the problem, In N. has requested a loan in the amount of $1100 to be used to buy a new motorcycle to provide transportation without hiring a taxi.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Tsedensodnom

texts.en:
Tsedensodnom M. is a 40-year-old handicapped person who lives with his wife and son in Huvsgul province, western of Mongolia in their own ger--a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His wife sews clothes at their home while his son works for a local road construction company as a carpenter. 

Tsedensodnom operates a taxi service between the countryside and the capital of the province. He and his wife started a sewing business in 1996 with the help of his younger sister and they sell their products out of a local trade market. He repairs his car with his transportation earnings and works very hard to provide for his family. He says, “My only wish is to support my son's education and have him become a good person”. 

Tsedensodnom is a hard working, creative person who wants to enlarge his business line and always encourages his wife's sewing business. He is requesting a 2,500,000 Mongolian tugrug MNT loan to purchase more fabrics and finishing materials for his famliy business.

loans.use: To purchase more fabrics and materials

loans.name: Rasheedan's Group

texts.en:
Rasheedan is a resident of Borewala city, which is located in south Punjab, Pakistan. She is a housewife, staying at home to manage the household chores. She is a 55-year-old lady who moved here to this city six years ago with her family. 

She is the mother of three sons; one of them is illiterate, while the other two left their education after passing their 5th standard. They had to start working to support their family financially. Her eldest son is involved in the business of making shoes while the other two have a business of timber selling.

Rasheedan has applied for a loan from Asasah for her eldest son. With the loan amount, he will buy raw materials, such as leather, nails and shoe polish, for making a larger quantity of shoes. He has been doing this business for over 10 years and is very good in his art. 

Rasheedan is hopeful that the loan amount will enable her son to make more money with his business and help him to fulfill larger orders on time. She is in her third loan cycle and has maintained a good credit record in the previous two years of loan cycles.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials for the shoe-making business

loans.name: Jennylyn

texts.en: Jennylyn M. is from the village of Brgy. Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 35 years old. Jennylyn is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Jennylyn sells personal products in the local community. Jennylyn has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 6,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2008, Jennylyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jennylyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jennylyn is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Jennylyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Imtiaz

texts.en:
Imtiaz lives in a city called Borewala, with her family, in Pakistan. She is 25 years old, is a housewife, and has one daughter and a son. They are both illiterate because Imtiaz is not in a position to afford their school fees.

Her husband paints walls and buildings and is the only breadwinner in the family. Sometimes he manages to get work and sometimes not, it is very difficult for Imtiaz to survive financially. She has applied for a loan from Asasah to financially support her husband, who will buy different colors of paint boxes in order to offer better services to his clients.

Imtiaz is hopeful that with an improved business condition, she will be able to send her children to school some day. This is the first time she has applied for a loan to any MFI. She hopes that it will be a profitable experience for her and for her family as well.

loans.use: To purchase paint boxes for paint business.

loans.name: Nazeeran's Group

texts.en:
Nazeeran has applied for a loan from Asasah to help her husband, who sells crockery sets, cups, jugs, etc. from a cart. He sells them by visiting different streets of the city named Borewala. Nazeeran moved to this city with her husband few years ago. She embroiders clothes for her neighborhood clients to fulfill the needs of her family.

She is the mother of a son and daughter who couldn’t get an education due to financial constraints.

With the help of a loan, Nazeeran will buy different crockery sets, cups, etc. for her husband to sell. She wants him to be successful in his business and that’s why she always supports him through every difficult time. This is the first time she has acquired a loan from any MFI, and she hopes that her husband will be able to improve his business. With the help of this investment Nazeeran’s family will be able to enjoy the basic necessities of life.

Note: In this photo, Rabia, a group member, shows her clothes selling business.

loans.use: To purchase crockery sets to sell.

texts.en:
Jurabek K. lives in the town of Kulob. He is 42 years old. He is married and has six children. His wife is a homemaker. Jurabek does not have high education. He has been selling on the market for more than five years. He has a store where he sells meat. He is taking out a loan to buy large cattle. He wants to expand his business and improve the financial situation of his family.

Translated from Russian by Elena Bortnikoff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane D. is from the city of San Jose, Santiago City. She is 35 years old. Mary Jane is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Jane owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from vending snacks such as pancit (a noodle dish), sopas (a chicken dish), and other street food. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 2,800 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mary Jane joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Mary Jane from ASKI. loans.name: Flavia

texts.en: Flavia A. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Bagumbayan, Bgry. 7, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a used clothing (ukay-ukay) business. Her husband Sabino A., who is 56 years old, works as a retailer of used clothing to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have seven children who are between 19 and 30 years old. Flavia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Flavia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 19,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20.000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 19th loan cycle, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to use to buy used clothing to sell so that she could continue to save up for the future and for rolling capital. Flavia A. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/lend/223451

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita S. is a married woman who lives in Barangay Rafaela Barrera within Sagay City, Negros Occidental province in the Western Visayas islands. Her husband Felix S., who is 59 years old, works as a personal driver to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are between 26 to 32 years old. Clarita earns her living by operating Ready-To-Wear clothing business.

Clarita joined NWTF’s Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from Project Dungganon, Clarita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 18000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 11000 PHP and lifted the family's standard of living.

This cycle loan, her 19th, she is borrowing 18000 PHP to obtain more capital for Ready-To-Wear so that she can continue to save up for future financial needs and to improve their living conditions. Clarita S. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They are on a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Laziya

texts.en: Laziya N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is single and has two children, both currently in school. Laziya has a business selling matooke (green plantain), which she has had for six years. To help expand her business, Laziya has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more matooke. With the help of the loan she hopes to generate greater profits and be able to buy food and educate her children. In the future, Laziya hopes to own a house. Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva that funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterwards, ELA participants can receive micro-finance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional micro-finance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in micro-finance.

loans.use: To buy more food like matooke

loans.name: Namyoya Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Forty-eight-year-old Grace M. describes herself as honest, friendly and easily approachable. These virtues, she says, have won her stripes and laurels in the 10 years she has been at the helm of a clothes-selling business in Seeta-Mukono. Her customers cut across from the lowest common denominators to the middle-class people around Seeta trading center-Mukono. In a week, she makes 200,000 shillings. With the profits, she can confidently say she has been able to make ends meet. She was previously partial to an agricultural cash-crop selling business. 

With this loan, this widowed mother of six wants to buy more clothes for reselling. She also wants to use part of this money to start a commercial poultry business.

loans.use: The purchase of more clothes for reselling and also the purchase of poultry

loans.name: Nonie

texts.en:
Nonie A. is from the village of Poblacion, Maranding, Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 29 years old. Nonie is widowed and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Nonie owns & operates a business repairing items such as sofa beds and their inner foam to local community members. Nonie has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Nonie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Nonie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Nonie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service.

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth C. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Lunas, Barangay Kawit, Medellin, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures:   food vending/carenderia, a general store and a trisikad business. Her husband Angelito C., 32 years old, works as a carpenter & trisikad driver to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  

They have 6 children who are between 9 and 24 years old. Lilibeth joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in March, 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 4 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lilibeth has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 18000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 5th loan, she is borrowing PHP 10000, which she intends to use to buy more food and inventory for the general store so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Lilibeth C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani lives in Borewala, with her family, which is a small city of Pakistan. She is a 35 year old lady who sews clothes for her neighborhood clients. She collects orders from them and fulfills them in time to earn an income. She gets 100 PKRs for simple sewing, and her designer sewing is sold for 150 PKRs, which her customers can easily pay her. She utilizes her income to pay for the utilities.
  
Her husband runs a grocery shop near the market. He offers different daily use products to his clients. Rani has given birth to a daughter and a son. Both of them are illiterate, and her son is a hairdresser by profession. Her daughter stays at home and manages the household chores and also helps her mother in her sewing work.

She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will put more groceries in his grocery shop. She hopes that by adding more variety, her husband can make more income by offering more to his clients. Rani is in her second loan cycle, earlier she received a loan for her son who started a barber shop which is going well now.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for grocery shop.

loans.name: Cristeta

texts.en:
Cristeta A. is from the village of Bayabo East, Tumauini, Isabela. She is 37 years old. Cristeta is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Cristeta owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Cristeta has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP when she sells her raised animals.

In 2009, Cristeta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cristeta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. Cristeta is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Cristeta from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future.

loans.name: Milka

texts.en:
Milka J. M. is a thirty-eight year old lady, married to Evans Rono, and they are blessed with two lovely children. Milka owns a shop at Moi refferal Hospital in Eldoret town, where she sells confectioneries, washing soap, washing detergents, fruits, and drinking water to the in-patient people at the Hospital. She has been in this business for five years now, and she gets a monthly income of 12,000 shillings. 

This will be Milka's fourth loan in KADET, and she plans to repair her shop, which sometimes leaks in the rainy season, to buy more stock for her business like washing detergent, drinking water, etc. With the income she gets she plans to expand her shop and have a bigger shop, and support her husband in providing for the family's basic needs.

In future, Milka plans to expand her business and even own a wholesale shop, and educate her children to the highest education level in Kenya.

loans.use: To buy confectioneries, washing detergent, drinking water, etc.

loans.name: Rocelyn

texts.en:
Rocelyn B. lives in Brgy. Pandan, Bogo, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures: Direct Selling (Personal Collection), Tricycle Operator, and Jewelry business. Her common-law husband, Jerry Dela Cruz, who is 40 years old, works as a Policeman to earn his living.  She has 2 children who are 5 years old and 8 years old.

Rocelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007, because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 6 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rocelyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 40,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 7th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000, which she intends to use as additional working capital, so that she can continue to save for the future education of her children, to buy her own land, and build her own house. Rocelyn B. is a Dungganon woman, who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon -a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Melona

texts.en:
Melona is from Nocnocan, Talibon. She is 30 years old, married, and has 5 school-aged children. She is involved in fishing. Her husband, who is a fisherman too, goes out fishing and she sells his catch at the market. She also dries fish sometimes and sells it in her community.

Melona joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI, and is now requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase a fishing boat. This will be Melona’s fourth loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her family’s house.

loans.use: to purchase a fishing boat

loans.name: Shakeela's Group

texts.en:
Shakeela is a 45-year-old housewife who lives in Borewala, Pakistan. She has four sons and two daughters.  Her eldest son is illiterate and works as a laborer. He couldn’t get an education due to financial problems, but now his financial situation has changed, and his younger brothers and sisters are able to attend school because of his financial support. 

Shakeela has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. He sells vegetables, and will be investing the loan money in his business by purchasing seasonal vegetables. Shakeela hopes that her family’s financial condition will improve through this venture. This is her 2nd loan from Asasah; her previous loan for the improvement of her husband’s business resulted in good profits, and she is expecting the same again.

loans.use: to purchase seasonal vegetables for reselling

Sâr N. was married, but divorced her husband some years ago. She has three children; two daughters are employed in a garment factory. She will use her loan to buy more tailoring tools to perform her service.

loans.name: Jackie

texts.en: Jackie N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is married and has one child, who is currently in school. Jackie has a business selling clothes, which she has had for less than one year. To help expand her business, Jackie has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Jackie hopes to generate greater profits and treat her cancer sickness. In the future, Jackie hopes to own a shop and educate her child. Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is single and has 3 children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Norah has a bar business, which she has had for 4 years.    

To help expand her business, Norah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more drinks like beer.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Norah hopes to generate greater profits to buy food and educate her children.  In the future, Norah hopes to own a house and to see her children go up to university.  

<b>Note to Lenders:<b/>
BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.

These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans to give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: to buy more drinks like beer

loans.name: Amabelle

texts.en: Amabelle V. is separated and lives in Purok Lubi, Barangay Tiglawigan, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures: a general store, raising hogs and selling cosmetics. Amabelle joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 3 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Amabelle has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 9,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 10,000 PHP, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 4th loan, she is borrowing 11,000 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase more stock for her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future to support her family's basic needs and for her children’s education. Amabelle V. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team page and become a part of our team.

loans.use: Purchase of goods for general store

loans.name: Battsengel

texts.en:
Battsengel D. is 37 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in the Huvsgul province of western Mongolia in their own ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent. Battsengel has been managing his taxi service between the countryside and the capital of the province since 2005, while his wife began selling firewood at retail prices in 2007 at her town market. 

As a result of a many years of business operation, Battsengel has become experienced at repairing vehicles as well. His wife has also created a wide customer base, which enables her to sell firewood fast. The two work very hard to provide for their family and are optimistic about their future. 

Battsengel and his wife hope one day to grow their businesses by creating their own workplace where they could sell firewood as well as operate a car-repair service. Batssengel is requesting a 1,000,000 Mongolian Tugriks loan to purchase parts for his automobile and a large amount of firewood for his wife's business in order to resell during the upcoming cold season.

loans.use: To purchase parts for his automobile and a large amount of firewood

loans.name: Yin

texts.en:
Yin M. is 36 years of age and a married woman. In order to meet the needs of the family, Yin M. sells a little grocery inventory out of her home. She has eight years of experience in this sector and is earning approximately $5.33 per day. To help contribute to the family, her husband built a small workshop where he provides a vehicle washing service.

This couple has been married for years and they have three kids who attend school. Yin M.’s husband normally uses a machine for pumping water to clean up any vehicles but unfortunately, the machine is not processing well and it may need repairs. Because of that, Yin M. has asked for a loan to repair an old pumping machine.

loans.use: To repair an old pumping machine for the vehicle-washing business

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma R. is from the town of Talibon. She is 43 years old. Emma is married and has an 18-year-old child. To make a living, Emma runs a general store to sell a variety of different products in the local community. She also cooks meals that she displays at her store. Emma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma is requesting a new loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and raw ingredients for cooking. This will be the first loan taken out by Emma from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc., (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance and training programs through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell and raw ingredients for cooking

Perlita has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. This will be the 18th loan taken out by Perlita from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and to financially support her family.

loans.name: Evanjelyn

texts.en:

The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling personal products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Evanjelyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Evanjelyn from HSPFI. loans.name: Emeliana

texts.en:
Emeliana M. is a 49-year old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: a coffee shop, a fish vending business, and a pig fattening business.  She lives in Purok 1, Brgy. Culipapa, Hinobaan, Negros Occidental.  

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her coffee shop, fish vending, and pig fattening businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 3000. 

Emeliana is now borrowing PHP 25,000 so she can purchase additional stocks. This is her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 23,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Emeliana aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the poverty-alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join the team.

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen lives in a two-room brick house in a small city called Borewala in Pakistan. She is 40 years of age and has spent all her life in Borewala. She is a seamstress and sews clothes on order. She is very good at her art and loves her work. She gets regular orders and a reasonably good income. 

Her husband is involved in the business of selling construction supplies. She has three sons and two daughters who are all studying except the eldest one who couldn’t start his education but started doing work to support the family. He has a furniture-making business which is going very well but he must invest his profit into it when he gets the large order from his customers.
 
Therefore, Yasmeen has applied for a loan from Asasah to help her son. With the loan amount, he will buy the required items, such as wood, wood polish and nails in large quantity, and fulfill the orders as well. 

This is the second time Yasmeen has applied for a loan from Asasah. She is very much sure that her son will be able to get more profit from his business and also be able to save money.

loans.use: Purchase required items for furniture-making business

loans.name: Samina's Group

texts.en:
Samina lives in a small city called Borewala which is located in Punjab Pakistan. She is 38 years old, and she stays at home to take care of her household responsibilities. 

Her husband is a rickshaw driver. He has been driving for the last 15 years. He used to drive a local bus but three years ago he started driving a rented rickshaw because of the difficult timings of bus driving. Now he has decided to start his own rickshaw business. In this way, he will make more income for his family because he won't have to pay the rental cost to the owner. Therefore, Samina has applied for a loan from Asasah to help her husband buy his own rickshaw.

She has a son who works in a motor-workshop. Samina wants her son to marry, and she is hopeful that she will be able to save money from the increased profits so she will be able to marry him off. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and has good track record. She never missed a single meeting. She is in her third loan cycle.

loans.use: Purchase a rickshaw

loans.name: Leticia's Group

texts.en:
Leticia P. is from the village of Brgy. Darubba, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 59 years old. Leticia is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Leticia is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Leticia owns and operates a business venture in the services sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing rice processing to local community members. Leticia has been involved in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Leticia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and gain the ability to engage in business activities. Leticia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Leticia is requesting a new loan to be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Leticia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Otgonbat

texts.en: Otgonbat L. is 32-years-old and lives with her husband and two children in Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. While her husband helps her out with her business producing wooden items in their town, her two daughters attend a middle school. The business is very family-oriented. Her husband designs and produces their products, such as frames for mirrors and portraits, while Otgonbat paints and decorates them. The couple started their wooden products business in 1997. The business has been successful and they have grown a stable operation. Otgonbat attributes her success to the quality of her products, which are much desired by her customers. Otgonbat says, "My husband and I are planning to expand our business to making ger furniture and assemblies. We are trying our best to finish our new house in which we would be more comfortable than today." She is a hard-working and modest woman that is requesting a loan to purchase more wood and paints for their products business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and paints

To make a living, Virginia sells health and medicinal products in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over a year now. Virginia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She also plans to buy piglets to start venturing into hog-raising. This will be the first loan taken out by Virginia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. loans.name: Pring

texts.en:
Pring P. is a 24-year-old villager who earns a living by sewing clothes in the garment factory. Pring P. is married to Mr. Noeuv Pirin, age 24, who works as a security guard. This couple has two small, school-aged kids. 

Pring P. and her husband currently reside together in a parent’s house. They wish to live independently by building a new house to live in, but their wish doesn’t come true because of a lack funds. To help achieve their goal, Pring P. is pursuing a loan to add with her personal savings in order to build a new house.

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Maqboolan's Group

texts.en:
Maqboolan is married to M. H. and has lived in a city called Borewala in Pakistan for the last 20 years. She is a 49-year-old lady who does embroidery to earn a living for her family. She has a reputation as being excellent in her art and gets regular orders. 

Her husband is a daily-wage labor. He doesn’t get regular work, that’s why Maqboolan has to work full-time to support her husband financially and to run the finances of the family smoothly.
 
She is the mother of three sons and three daughters. Her eldest son is a tailor and the second one is an electrician. Her youngest son is in 2nd standard. Her daughters are also studying, except the eldest one, who couldn’t get an education due to financial reasons. 

Maqboolan has applied for a loan from Asasah for her elder son. With the loan amount, he will buy a sewing machine and also hire a worker who will help him in fulfilling larger orders on time. 

Maqboolan is hopeful that she will be able to improve her family’s financial condition with the help of increased profits from her son’s business. She is in her second loan cycle and has proven to be a responsible loan user of Asasah.

loans.use: Purchase a sewing machine for a tailoring business

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome E. is a 49-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 business ventures: fishing and fish vending. She lives in Prk. 2, Brgy. Inalad, Siaton, Negros Oriental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fish vending business, she was able to purchase her own fishing boat and she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP8,000. 

Salome is now borrowing PHP 22,000 so that she can purchase more fishing gear and other equipment. This will be her 7th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP17,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Salome aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.
