texts.en:
Mirriam Joy G. is from the village of Brgy. Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 24 years old, married and has 1 school-aged child. Mirriam Joy owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells personal products. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Mirriam Joy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. She is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Mirriam Joy from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita I. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Matapat, Brgy. San Jose, Puerto Princesa City, Palawan. She earns her living by operating 5 business ventures: a car shop, a general store, an eatery, a tailoring business and a frozen products business. Perlita's shop specializes in making motorcycle sidecars, repainting trucks and cars, and assembly of any type of vehicle. 

Her husband Neofito I., who is 56 years old, works as a Technician/Driver/Mechanic to earn a living. They have 2 children who are 26 and 27 years old. 

Perlita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Perlita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 28,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 25,000, thus elevating the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 50,000. She intends to use the loan to purchase a passenger bus so that she can continue to save  for future investments and for her family. Perlita I. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase a passenger bus

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ham

texts.en: Horm S. is 70 years old and sells Khmer noodles by moving through residential areas, earning about $1.80 each day. She is married to Phum Phan, a bricklayer who moves from construction site to construction site and earns about $2.50 each day. Together they have six children, only one of whom is married. The other five children contribute to the family's income by working as restaurant waiters, souvenir salespeople and peddlers of used goods. To increase her family's income, Horm S. plans to invest in a new business by building a small store next to her house where she can sell food. As she does not have capital, Horm S. decided to request a Kiva loan to make this action possible.

loans.use: To build a small store next to her house to sell food

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa B. is from the village of Abu, Baylao, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old. Elsa is married and has 1 infant. She owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells food & daily use products. Elsa has been engaged in her business for over 1 year.

In 2000, Elsa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Elsa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase tools

loans.name: Janarietta

texts.en:
Janarietta E. is from the town of Talibon. She is 37 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Janarietta owns & operates a general store where she sells a variety of products. She has doing this for over two years now. She also spends time selling fish around her community. She buys fresh fish from fishermen and goes around her neighborhood selling it.

Janarietta joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products, and also fish, to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Janarietta from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to make improvements to their house and living conditions. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products and fish to resell

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah K. lives in the Kimwanyi zone in Katanga Wandegeya neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married  to a primary school teacher. They have 5 children, all of whom are in school.  Sarah has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 8 years and she works 7 days a week. Sarah sells her products, retail, at the market. She has requested a loan of 900,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO which she will use to buy additional bags of charcoal.  She also generates additional income through a catering business.

The main business challenges for Sarah include transportation costs. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to be a successful business lady. She decided to join MCDT because she is trustworthy. Sarah lives in a home that she owns and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal

loans.name: Tom

texts.en:
Tom M. dropped out of school.  He began his bar and lodging business in Jinja town 2 years ago. At the relatively young age of 27, he already has 3 children.  He has been meeting the challenge of caring for his children through his weekly earnings of about 100,000 shillings.

With this loan, Tom plans to purchase more crates of drinks for his bar and bedding for his lodge.

loans.use: To purchase drinks for his pub and bedding for his lodge.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean G. is from the village of Abu, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 31 years old and married, with 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Jean  sells specialty food products such as steamed-rice cakes. Jean has been engaged in her business for more than 2 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

Jean joined HSPFI this year o gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jean is requesting her first loan from HSPFI, for 5000 PHP.  The money will be used to purchase raw ingredients to make products for sale. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Bushra Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Bushra perveen lives in a small city called Borewala which is located in the Punjab province of Pakistan. She came to Borewala after her marriage to A. who runs a business selling towels and handkerchiefs.

Bushra is 39 years old and a caring lady who stays at home to manage the household chores. She also helps her husband in arranging his towels and handkerchiefs in an appropriate way so he finds them easily to meet the orders of his customers.

Bushra has four sons and two daughters. Two of her sons are illiterate and operate their businesses separately. Her other two sons are receiving an education and are in 2nd and 5th standard respectively. Her two daughters are also attending school and study in grade 7th and 10th standard.

Bushra lives with her family members in a small house of two rooms. She has converted her house into a home with her excellent management qualities.

Bushra has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who wants to expand his business of selling towels and handkerchiefs. With the loan amount he will buy towels and handkerchiefs in bulk and increase his sales. Bushra is hopeful that her husband will be able to improve his business with this loan investment.

loans.use: To purchase more towels and handkerchiefs in bulk for her husband's business

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Every morning, Mrs. Sim R. travels to the market where she frequently buys ingredients that she uses to make traditional cakes. She makes the cakes at her house before selling them to villagers for a profit. Another source of family income comes from her husband, who works driving a motor-taxi. The couple has four children who are already married.

Sim R. has a son who makes wooden furniture, but his income is not very much as his business has come to a low capacity due to insufficient financial capital. Sim R. is taking out her loan to increase the capital of her son’s investment, which will allow him to improve his profit.

loans.use: To increase the capital of her son's furniture-making business

loans.name: Marisa

texts.en: Marisa P. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 36 years old and is married with three school-aged children. Marisa owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling and dealing in personal products such as clothes and shoes in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Marisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase tools and equipment for his television-repair business

loans.name: Jolete

texts.en:
Jolete M. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, bread and onions at the market and is requesting a loan to stock cooking oil to sell.

Jolete is 51 years old and is widowed. She has seven children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business by stocking bags of maize flour to sell.

loans.use: To stock cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Picking somebody’s brains to make use of his or her ideas is not something new in business, as 43-year-old M. Stephen will attest. Some may call it emulating, but this may go beyond that as one may try to painstakingly make deductions of how a particular individual’s business plans were brought to fruition.

This is the course of action Stephen took after dropping out of school. First he was a shamba boy (a gardener or field hand). The thought of remaining a shamba boy all his life unnerved him very much. He knew the future was not that rosy with odd jobs like that.

At length, after studying most of his closest friends, Stephen began his poultry business. As the saying goes, the rest is history as he has made steady strides ever since. This business brings him 700,000 shillings a month and he is one happy man. He also supplements these profits with earnings from coffee and milk sales.

With this loan, Stephen is looking at buying more chickens and chicken feed for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more chickens and chicken feed for his business

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en: Maricel R. is from the village of Yumbing, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 33 years old, is single, and has four school-aged children. Maricel owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling and dealing in personal products such as clothes and shoes in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Maricel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Farzana's Group

texts.en:
Farzana is 35 years old and is married to N. H.. They have lived in Borewala, Pakistan, for the last four years. She is the mother of two daughters who are of 5 and 3 years old and have not yet started going to school. She has a wish to send them into school so they never have to face the financial problems which she faced.

Farzana sews clothes for her nearby clients. Her husband is a painter who paints walls, doors and windows to order and generates income. He doesn’t get regular orders and that’s why Farzana pays full-time attention to her sewing business so she makes suitable earnings to run her household finances.

Farzana has applied for a loan for the third time from Asasah, this time to improve her sewing business. She will buy an electric sewing machine which will help her to work more efficiently. She is hopeful that her business will be in a better position and that she will be able to increase her income.

In the photo, Farzana is showing one of her prepared dresses.

loans.use: To purchase an electric sewing machine for her sewing business

loans.name: Dul

texts.en:
Mrs. Dul D. has been in the farming business for years. She plants various crops to earn a living and typically generates an income of $3 per day. Her husband works in the farm fields with her.

The coming rainfall season is the time when it is easy to plant crops. However, Dul D. doesn’t have any supplies to use on her field. She now requests a $200 loan to be used to purchase fertilizer and seed to plant.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and seed to plant

loans.name: Kasifa

texts.en:
Kasifa N. lives in the Naguru neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has seven children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of an additional family member. She lives in a home that she rents and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

Kasifa has a business selling yellow bananas in Nakawa Market. She has been in this business for ten years, and works three days a week. She has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy additional bunches of yellow bananas.

Kasifa’s main business challenges include seasonality and the ever-increasing prices of bananas. Her goals and aspirations are to increase the size of her business and obtain additional capital.

Kasifa decided to work with MCDT because she wanted additional capital and because of its good customer care.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of yellow bananas to sell

loans.name: Santina

texts.en: Santina K. is currently in the business of selling clothes and bedsheets at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock more bedsheets to sell.  Santina is 39 years old and is married; her husband is a business man. She has two children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a sewing machine.

loans.use: To stock more bedsheets to sell

loans.name: Benkadi 3 (Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe BENKADI 3 sont  de femmes mariées du village de WARASSO dans l’ex l’arrondissement de Kimparana (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 35 ans et  7 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide, du pois de terre et du maïs. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année. 
KADIA D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels agricoles et des intrants pour la culture, exclusivement  au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
KADIA D. compte réaliser, après l’écoulement de ses produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 40.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Benkadi 3 gropu are married women from the village of Warasso located near the region of Kimparana (the fourth administrative region in the Republic of Mali). They all have traditional families and on average they are 35 years old, with 7 children. They harvest peanuts, peas and corn. Kadia D. plans on investing the funds to purchase a large enough quantity of peanut seeds and other miscellaneous agricultural materials from the Kimparana market. After the winter months the harvest is stocked away until that time that the asking price can be improved. The harvest will be sold in the Kimparana market and other neighbouring markets. The sales can be finalized as wholesale and can be paid for in cash. The clientele usually comes from larger cities. Kadia D. will earn, following the sale of her harvest, a profit of 40 FCFA and these earnings will be used to repay the loan and the interest, and it will also be used to cover the family's expenses.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase seeds and other agricultural materials.

loans.name: Fahmida Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Fahmida nasreen lives in the small city of Borewala in Pakistan. She is 37 years old and sells ready-made clothes to support her family. Her husband has a furniture showroom in a nearby market where he displays his handmade furniture such as bedroom sets, chairs, tables, etc. His business is going well and gives him a good income. 

Fahmida is very supportive in nature. She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her brother, who also lives with her as a family member. He has a business selling car batteries from a shop in a nearby market. With the help of a loan, he will buy batteries in larger quantities so he can fulfill orders more quickly. He has been in this business for more than five years and believes there is potential to make good money from this business in Pakistan. 

Fahmida nasreen is hopeful that her brother will be able to stand on his feet and improve his business with the help of this investment. This is her second loan. She is a responsible loan user of Asasah and has a good credit record.

loans.use: To purchase car batteries for resale

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is 43 years old and is married with eight children. He owns a grinding machine that he uses for grinding cassava, sorghum and some other agriculture products. The hours of his business are from morning hours until late in the evening.

Jean, after realizing that the number of his customers has increased, wants to open another business area where he will operate the same business. To end this, he is requesting a Kiva loan so that he can purchase an additional grinding machine.

With this additional machine, Jean hopes that he will be able to satisfy his customers and, in addition to that, earn a lot of profits. These profits will hopefully allow him to continue taking care of his family and start saving for his future.

loans.use: To buy another grinding machine

loans.name: Flora

texts.en: Flora N. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and dried fish at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock more dried fish, as well as fresh ones, to sell. Flora is 43 years old and is married; her husband is a police man. She has four children, three of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: To stock more dried and fresh fish to sell

loans.name: Nsindika Njake Womens Group-Kayunga

texts.en:
The first step to any success in any kind of undertaking is determination. From his early days as a tailor, which was his first business venture, 42 year old L. Isa, a high spirited and courteous married gentleman with 4 children, has laid great store on the values of hard work. This attitude, combined with his never tiring and determined resolve has brought him dividends in his agro-produce sales business. Because the cash crop he primarily sells at his stall, which is maize, is in high favour with most people around Namirembe in Kayunga, he has been able to make and consolidate his steady profits. 

This flourishing period, however, is mostly during the months of July and August when he is able to harvest on a large scale from his gardens. The recurring months are for drying and selling. This means that the seasons that lie at the threshold of every year and at the end of it are normally stagnant ones as he has less to sell, even if he has reserves. He also has to constantly bear in mind the provision of proper welfare to his family. This means he has to use some of his maize reserves as food for his family. He credits his dad for inspiring him and he has, ever since then, worked hard to emulate him. This has manifested itself in the 120,000 shillings, he makes in a week. His business longevity now stretches to a period of 12 years and, under the auspices of this loan, he wants to purchase in bulk more bags of maize to resell.  The upshot, he says, is that he will be able to consolidate on his financial base with the increased sales.

loans.use: The purchase in bulk of more bags of maize for reselling.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: She wants to expand and progress her business.

loans.name: Tetyana

texts.en:
Tetyana sells clothing and shoes at the central market in Kherson. She has been in this business for 10 years. Her net profit is 3,000 Grivnas per month.

Tetyana is the kind of person who, if she decides to do something, goes slowly and persistently until she reaches her goal. When she first started this business, she really wanted to become economically independent. She has now reached this goal. Today, she has many repeat clients and a stable business. Tetyana is very friendly and has good relationships with her neighbors at the market. 

Tetyana would like to take a loan to purchase additional inventories. She hopes to attract new customers and make additional profit. 

Tetyana lives in a house with her husband and son.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing and shoes

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes P. is currently in the business of selling ice cream, orange juice and soda in the shop and is requesting a loan to stock mango juice to sell.  Agnes is 42 years old and is married. Her husband is a business man. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her shop into a bar.

loans.use: Stock mango juice to sell.

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Van N. is a 44-year-old married woman and local villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Battambang Province. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. In addition, Van N. owns a rice cultivating machine with which she can provide a plowing service to her neighbors. The couple has three young kids who are no longer in school and currently work at different occupations. Van N. will be using the half of the loan she requested to build a stall next to her house where she raises a few pigs for extra profit. With the rest of the loan, Van N. will fund her efforts in cultivating rice crops.

loans.use: To build a stall and towards cultivating rice crops.

loans.name: Benkadi 4 (Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Le huit membres du groupe BENKADI 4 sont  des femmes mariées du village de WARASSO dans l’ex l’arrondissement de Kimparana, du cercle de SAN, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ayant en moyenne 38  ans et au moins 5 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide, le petit mil et du maïs. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe Benkadi IV WARASSO ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année. 
FANTA MADOU T. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture,   au grand marché de Kimparana ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Tan disque  les autres membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 20 000 à 40.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille, FANTA MADOU T., espère obtenir  65.000FCFA en fin de campagne
texts.en:
The eight members of the Benkadi 4 group are married women from the village of Warasso, part of the former Kimparana borough in the San district of the Segou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families, are on average 38 years old with at least five children. They cultivate peanuts, mil and corn. Wishing to improve the return on their farming activities, the members of the Benkadi 4 Warasso group decided this year to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit loan programme. Fanta Madou T. will use her loan to buy a sufficient quantity of peanut seedlings, farming tools and fertilizer at the main market of Kimparana. Following the winter season, the crops are stocked for a certain period to increase their value before being sold at the main Kimparana market and markets in the surrounding area. They are sold retail (and often wholesale) mainly to customers coming from large towns. Whereas other group members hope to reach individual profits ranging from 20,000 to 40,000 FCFA after selling their agricultural products, Fanta Madou T. hopes her earnings will reach 65,000 FCFA by the end of the season. The profits will be used to reimburse loan interests and to cover daily family expenses.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Achat  d’intrants, semences  et petits matériels. Buy fertilizer, seedlings and farming tools

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet G. is from the village of San Jose, Centro Enrile, Cagayan. She is 31 years old. Juliet is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Juliet owns & operates a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Juliet has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Juliet joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juliet has successfully repaid a previous loan of 22,000 PHP from ASKI. Juliet is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Juliet from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sakina's Group

texts.en:
Sakina lives in a small city called Borewala which is located in Punjab province of Pakistan. She is a 39 year old lady who has spent most of her life in Borewala. She is the mother of four sons: two of whom are studying and the remaining two are running their businesses. The eldest one is a butcher and deals with chicken meat specifically while the second son has a business of hosiery. Sakina herself supplies baby pampers to different shops, on order. 

Sakina has applied for a loan from Asasah for her elder son. With the loan amount he will buy chicken in bulk because EID Season (Muslims' occasion for celebration, which comes after Ramadan) is near and after Ramadan, the wedding season will be starting and the demand for chicken will be increased. So Sakina is very sure that her son will be able to make good income in these seasons.  

Sakina is in her 2nd loan cycle. Earlier she invested loan money in her son’s business of hosiery, which resulted in increase of profits for him. She has proven herself to be a very responsible loan user of Asasah in her first year of loan.

loans.use: Purchase chicken in bulk for chicken meat selling business.

loans.name: Viola

texts.en: Viola J.  is currently in the business of selling various items in the shop such as bags of sugar, salt, biscuits etc and is requesting a loan to stock bags of rice and beans to sell. Viola is 39 years old and is married. Her husband is a business man. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her shop by building another floor.

loans.use: Stock bags of rice and beans to sell.

loans.name: Rinalyn

texts.en:
Rinalyn G. is from the village of Benhaan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 31 years old. Rinalyn is single and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Rinalyn owns & operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for sale. Rinalyn has been engaged in her business for over 1 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rinalyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rinalyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Rinalyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Towards purchasing a new carpet frame.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan P. is currently in the business of selling charcoal from home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal and some firewood to sell.  Susan is 57 years old and is widowed. She has 7 children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal and some firewood to sell.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia lives in a small city called Borewala located in south Punjab Pakistan. She is 47 years old and has been living in this city for the last 13 years with her husband, an electrician,  and four children. One daughter is a teacher in nearby school; her eldest son is also an electrician.  Razia owns and operates a sewing business to support her family financially. She takes orders for clothing from her nearby community and generates income by completing them. 

Razia’s husband wants to expand his business by buying more electric tools so that both he and her son will be able to serve for more customers. Presently, they both use the same tools resulting in one of them having to wait for the other to be finished with the tools.. Razia is hopeful that they will be able to successfully upgrade their business and improve the family’s financial condition. She is in her second loan cycle and is a responsible loan user of Asasah. 

Note: In this photo, Razia is showing one of her dress which she sews by herself.

loans.use: Purchase electric tools

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.en:
Gregoria B. is from the village of San Jose, Enrile, Cagayan. She is 52 years old, married, and has two adult children. To make a living, Gregoria owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Gregoria has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4300 PHP a month for these activities.

Gregoria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gregoria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. Gregoria is requesting a new loan of 23000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Gregoria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen/women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nan

texts.en: There are many Cambodians who make a living as rice cultivators; one of them is Mrs. Nan R. who has been working in this business since 1992. She and her husband grow rice on their own farmland that they inherited from their grandparents. From this business they can generate an income of around US $3 per day. In addition to their farming work, this humble couple takes time to fish in and around the river. The river is full of fish during the fishing season; however, the family does not have tools to use for fishing. Therefore, Nan R. has decided to seek assistance through Kiva’s field partner HKL in order to purchase fishing equipment.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment

loans.name: Ma. Nenita

texts.en:
Ma. Nenita B. is from the town of Talibon. She is 42 years old. Ma. Nenita is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Nenita owns and operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from gathering and selling "bat" (sea cucumber) to the market. She also sells fish sometimes.

Ma. Nenita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Nenita has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ma. Nenita is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding her business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en: Emelia K.  is currently in the business of selling necklaces, earrings, and women's saddles at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock bedsheets and dresses to sell. Emelia is 24 years old and is married; her husband is a business man. She has two children who do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop where she could sell from.

loans.use: To stock bedsheets and dresses to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy different kinds of thread and cloth to grow her business

loans.name: Aquiliano

texts.en:
Aquiliano T. is from the town of Talibon. He is 45 years old and is married.

Aquiliano owns and operates a fishing business, operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish to the market. 

Aquiliano joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. This loan will be his first from CEVI.

Aquiliano plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets

loans.name: Yann

texts.en:
Mrs. C. is 47 years of age and the widowed mother of four children, two of whom are already married and live separately and the other two are single and live at home. C. is a good homemaker who either takes care of her children or arranges a daily routine from home.

C. relies on the income from her single kids who work at various jobs: one is a vegetable seller and the other is a sewing laborer in industry.

C. has an old house that often needs repairs, so she would like to request a loan to mend it.

loans.use: To mend her old house

loans.name: Susah

texts.en:
Susah D. is currently in the business of selling dried fish at the market and is requesting a loan to stock onions, tomatoes and cooking oil to sell.

Susah is 51 years old and is widowed. She has seven children and four of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To stock onions, tomatoes and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda Q. is from the town of Rizal West, San Isidro. She is 46 years old. Melinda is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Melinda owns & operates a transportation business. The main source of income for the business comes from motorcycle transport. Melinda has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3800 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Melinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melinda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Melinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Seraphine

texts.en:
Seraphine is 47 years old, married with two children.  Seraphine makes a living by selling foodstuffs like bananas, sorghum, beans, etc.  She has been in this business for about 10 years and the hours of her business are from early in the morning until late in the evening.

 After realizing that her capital is still too low to expand meaningfully, Seraphine needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  By using this loan, Seraphine hopes that her sales as well as profits will increase.  If successful, she will use one portion of her profits in taking care of her family and another portion will be saved for a better financial stability in the future.

loans.use: A large quantity  of foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en: Emelia J. is currently in the business of selling women's headdresses and handbags at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bedsheets and trousers to sell.  Emelia is 34 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a real shop where she can display her goods.

loans.use: Stock bedsheets and trousers to sell

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita D. is from the town of Rizal West, San Isidro. She is 57 years old. Florita is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Florita owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Florita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Florita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Florita is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Florita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Promesse Plus Group

texts.en:
Virginie L. is the manager of the Community bank named “Promesse Plus”. It is composed of 23 members, united in solidarity for receiving Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses.

Virginie started her business in 2003 with a capital of US$ 20 selling yogurt. Today, she operates a general boutique. She is 42 years old, widowed, and has two children whose ages are 13 and 15. Both go to school. She has already received MFI HOPE DRC loans nine times and has fully repaid them. With the profit of about $80 earned per week, she intends with the next loan to increase the inventory of her business by buying canned goods, sugar, sacks of rice and beans and other items to resell at a profit. 

Currently, Virginie is happy to be part of one of Hope’s groups because her business has been reinforced through the loans she has received. Her dream is to someday become a wholesaler. She sells her goods in the western area of Kinshasa.

loans.use: reinforcing her working capital

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

texts.en: Agaeter M. is currently in the business of selling both dried and fresh red peppers at the market and is requesting a loan to stock dried tomatoes to sell. Agaeter is 48 years old and is widowed. She has five children, and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent out in order to pay her children's school fees in the higher institutions of learning.

loans.use: To stock dried tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Melony

Melony M. is from the town of Villa Rose Cabarroguis, Quirino. She is 36 years old. Melony is married and has 3 school-age children. To make a living, Melony owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Melony has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Melony joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melony has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Melony is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Melony from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Purchasing vegetable seeds

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John Q. is from the town of Talibon. He is 23 years old. John is married and has a 1-year-old child. He buys and re-sells fish and crabs. He has been involved in his business for 4 months now and he hopes to acquire more fish and crabs to sell. He rents a stall in his town's market where he sells his fish and crabs.

John joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. John is requesting a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by John from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to his house.

loans.use: business expansion

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty T. is currently in the business of washing and ironing customers' clothes at the laundry shop and is requesting a loan to stock more boxes of soap and washing powder. Betty is 33 years old and is married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

loans.use: Stock more boxes of soap and washing powder

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda C. is from the town of Talibon. She is 30 years old. Merlinda is married and has three school-aged children. Merlinda owns and operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from operating a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish at the market. Merlinda has been engaged in her business for over five years.

Merlinda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Merlinda is requesting a new loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Merlinda from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve it.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Flora

texts.en: Flora D. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, beans, onions, and Irish potatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of rice and maize flour to sell.  Flora is 37 years old and is married with a husband that is a policeman. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business by stocking cocks and hens to sell.

loans.use: Stock bags of rice and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Rhodora

texts.en:
Rhodora J. is from the town of Talibon. She is 30 years old. Rhodora is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Rhodora owns and operates a bakery. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from baking and selling bread in the local community. Rhodora has been engaged in her business for more than three years.

Rhodora joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rhodora is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional cooking ingredients like flour and sugar. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rhodora from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase cooking ingredients like flour and sugar

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria W. is currently in the business of selling bags of maize, millet, sorghum, and pealed dried cassava. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of maize and sorghum to sell. Victoria is 46 years old and is married; her husband is a small-scale farmer. She has three children who do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to send her children to school.

loans.use: To stock more bags of maize and sorghum
